review.title: Quantifying literature quality using complexity criteria
review.abstract: We measured entropy and symbolic diversity for English and Spanish texts including literature Nobel laureates and other famous authors. Entropy, symbol diversity and symbol frequency profiles were compared for these four groups. We also built a scale sensitive to the quality of writing and evaluated its relationship with the Flesch's readability index for English and the Szigriszt's perspicuity index for Spanish. Results suggest a correlation between entropy and word diversity with quality of writing. Text genre also influences the resulting entropy and diversity of the text. Results suggest the plausibility of automated quality assessment of texts.

metadata.title: Quantifying literature quality using complexity criteria

sections.text: We measured entropy and symbolic diversity for English and Spanish texts, including Nobel Laureates in Literature and other famous authors. Entropy, symbol diversity and symbol frequency profiles were compared for these four groups. We also developed a scale that is sensitive to the quality of writing, and evaluated its relationship to the Flesch reading comprehension index for English and the Szigriszt coherence index for Spanish. Results suggest a correlation between entropy and word diversity with the quality of writing. The text genre also influences the resulting entropy and text diversity. Results suggest the plausibility of an automated quality assessment of texts. Keywords entropy, complexity, readability, writing quality.

sections.heading: 2 Methods
sections.text: This work was based on a library of 166 English and 175 Spanish texts. The texts were grouped into two categories: one was integrated by these texts written by authors who won the Nobel Prize for Literature, the other was composed of texts by renowned writers, politicians, military and social figures. By combining writers and Nobel Prize winners in English and Spanish, we obtained four groups for our analyses. Each text was distinguished by its diversity of symbols, entropy and symbol frequency distribution according to the definitions below. We created a mathematical model with these properties for the four groups created. Means and dispersion were examined by statistical methods and cluster analyses.

sections.heading: 2.7 Message selection and groups
sections.text: This study is based on written texts from famous historical speeches available on the Internet. Originally, the texts were written in various languages, including English, Spanish, Portuguese, French, Italian, German, Japanese, Arabic, Russian, Chinese and Swedish. Since the analysis was conducted in English and Spanish, many of the texts used are translations from the original versions. Most of the texts come from politicians, human rights activists and Nobel laureates for literature. To complete the library, some fragments of novels have also been included. Fragments of novels correspond to English and Spanish writers, as well as Nobel laureates. We created speech groups and novel segments for English and Spanish: one group of texts with undoubtedly good linguistic users, those who have received the Nobel Prize for Literature, and another group of authors for whom we have no particular reason to assume an above-average use of the language. Texts written by a Nobel laureate are all in their original language; therefore, the Spanish version of a speech by Mácía Garrez, for example, is considered to be written as their translation in English. sections.heading: 4 Discussions
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Diversity and Entropy
sections.text: Nobel laureates in literature have a richer vocabulary in their speeches than other authors. Obviously, a necessary condition for a Nobel Prize is knowledge of an expanded lexicon and the wisdom to use it appropriately and with a properly organized style, which explains the higher word diversity in Nobel laureate texts presented in Figure 1. Nevertheless, the relatively higher diversity among Nobel laureates does not explain the lower entropy observed in Figure 2. If the shape of the frequency profile is determined, an increase in symbol diversity contributes to an increase in entropy. Therefore, the lower entropy shown in Nobel laureate texts must obey the structure of the symbols used, which overcomes the effect of the greater word diversity in their texts.

sections.heading: 4.2 Symbol Frequency Distribution Profile
sections.text: The relatively small p-values, however, indicate that Zipf's deviations express some of the differences between texts written by Nobel and non-Nobel laureates, and therefore justify the inclusion of Zipf's deviations as a sensitive factor for the quality of writing.

sections.heading: 4.3 Writing Quality Scale versus Readability index
sections.text: In fact, the assessment of quality and writing style is a highly subjective matter that is difficult to submit to a quantifiable procedure. It is a subtle and elusive task. However, a good writing structure and writing style must include readability as an important feature of the resulting text. Entropy standards studied here add information about more general aspects of writing quality. Another factor that affects the readability indices is the complexity of the idea used with the text. A complex idea probably cannot be explained by the same high readability index as a simple idea. Therefore, the question is: How readable can a writer write a text to convey a complex idea? There is no obvious answer, among other things, because the complexity of the idea itself is a subjective factor. But good writers should tend to produce more readable texts - with better readability indices: >? 6 for English and HI6 for graphics - than those who are less talented than the Spanish Nobel laureates for their high reading ability.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: Our analysis has shown that some characteristics of English and Spanish texts, such as entropy, diversity of symbols and frequency profiles, relate to aspects considered by professionals to be "good writing" in natural languages. This is encouraging because it suggests the possibility of applying quantitative measures to characterize certain aspects related to the quality of fonts, opening the door for the development of tools for automatic text evaluation. The fact that quality is associated with less entropy suggests that skillful writing involves not only the inclusion of grammar (Febres, Jaffé and Gershenson 2013), but also the inclusion of order in the text. The exact nature of this additional order is still unknown, but our method serves to detect its existence.The results found so far are to be considered findings from a preliminary study of the complexity of texts.
